content: I saw this this morning and I just wondered if anyone else knew of this. Here is the part that caught my attention: Parents must actively oppose this hijacking of the classroom for political purposes. The GBLT, the Athiests, the 'Religions Other Than Christianity', and 'everyone and their dog' want to let the school be school and to keep the "agendas" out of the schools. Their reasoning is sound, ('Don't indoctrinate their impressionable young minds. Allow their parents to guide them on moral decisions.), but they want to then turn around and "indoctrinate their impressionable young minds" onto their agenda. Feel free to comment. I almost put this on the "Gay in the Military" thread, but it's not about the military...it's about our children. Thankfully, mine have already graduated. Message follows: April 7, 2009 If your child's school allows "Day of Silence" propaganda, keep your child at home April 17 The Day of Silence, which is sponsored by the Gay, Lesbian and Straight Education Network (GLSEN), fast approaches. This year it will take place in most public schools on April 17. On this day, thousands of public high schools and increasing numbers of middle schools will allow students to remain silent throughout an entire day-even during instructional time-to promote GLSEN's socio-political goals and its controversial, unproven, and destructive theories on the nature and morality of homosexuality. Parents must actively oppose this hijacking of the classroom for political purposes. Please join the national effort -http://www.illinoisfamily.org/doswalkout- to restore to public education a proper understanding of the role of government-subsidized schools. You can help de-politicize the learning environment by calling your child out of school if your child's school allows students to remain silent during instructional time on the Day of Silence. Parents should no longer passively countenance the political usurpation of public school classrooms through student silence. If students will be permitted to remain silent, parents can express their opposition most effectively by calling their children out of school on the Day of Silence and sending letters of explanation to their administrators, their children’s teachers, and all school board members. One reason this is effective is that most school districts lose money for each student absence. School administrators err when they allow the classroom to be disrupted and politicized by granting students permission to remain silent throughout an entire day. Visit this website -http://www.illinoisfamily.org/doswalkout/ - for complete information on opposing the Day of Silence. Take Action! 1. Call your local schools and ask whether they permit students or teachers to remain silent in the classroom on “Day of Silence.” IMPORTANT: Do not ask any administrator, school board member, or teacher if the school sponsors, endorses, or supports DOS. Schools do not technically sponsor the Day of Silence. Technically, it is students, often students in the gay-straight alliance, who sponsor it. Many administrators will tell you that they do not sponsor the DOS when, in fact, they do permit students and sometimes even teachers to remain silent during instructional time. Also ask administrators whether they permit teachers to create lesson plans to accommodate student silence. 2. Find out what date the event is planned for your school. (The national date in 2009 is April 17, but some schools observe DOS on a different date). 3. Inform the school of your intention to keep your children home on that date and explain why. (A sample letter is available -http://www.illinoisfamily.org/content/img/f34263/sample-call-out-letter.doc- .) For more information or questions, visit Day of Silence Walkout -http://www.illinoisfamily.org/doswalkout/- These are my opinions. Yours may differ.

content: None of the children are obligated to remain silent. Basically, the kids who INDIVIDUALLY decide to participate will not be punished by their teachers for remaining silent. If a kid wants to do it, he or she can. If not, then it's a normal school day like any other... just a bit less noisy. And think about how wonderful it would be for the teachers! They can actually teach the classes without kids talking and causing a commotion. SILENCE! Such a wonderful thing in classrooms. I know teachers who would LOVE to teach a class to children who actually remain quiet in their seats during the lesson. In fact, conservatives love silence so much that they're absolutely obsessed with having a minute of silence at the start of each school day, so they should LOVE this!

content: I don't understand the purpose of this. Why bring political agendas into the classroom? It's petty. If a student refuses to participate, a teacher should act accordingly, same as that teacher always does, and not feel obligated in any way to cow-tow to a political agenda, regardless of what it is. Only the weak teachers will allow themselves to be intimidated by politics, and I strongly question whether or not those types of teachers actually have the mettle to really teach in the first place.

title: [B]"Day of Silence"[/B]

content: The way to fight this, if a student was so inclined, is not to run from it by staying at home. That would just legitimize the action. That Illinois Organization is dead wrong in their approach. Instead, if a student observes a school and a teacher who recognizes the Day of Silence, that student can come to the classroom the next day or the next week with their own personal "Day of Silence". As illegitimate as it may seem it has to be recognized as legitimate by that school and classroom by default. Let's say it's Pete's Personal Day Of Silence in rememberance of the plight of the polar bear. Fine. And if that school dares to punish Pete for his personal day of silence in recognition of the plight of the polar bear, then that classroom and that school are hypocrites, and should be held to account, perhaps legally so, because there's nothing inherently more legitimate about a group Day of Silence for homosexual rights than there is a personal day of silence for the rights of bears. The classroom shouldn't be corrupted with political agendas of any sort, but if the attempt is made, then dirty tactics can be fought with dirty tactics. Or legitimate tactics with legitimate tactics, if one prefers.

content: Is there a rule in your local school that students must talk? The day of silence allows for answering questions and participating in group dicsussion. This is not talking in the hall, in the lunchroom, or unless absolutely necessary. Are you going to punish kids for not talking to each other on this day? You people are off your rocker. I mean just READ about what you're supposed to get all bent out of shape about: quote: Parents should no longer passively countenance the political usurpation of public school classrooms through student silence. That sentence is the most laughable I've read in an activist email in years. I lifted the following passage from a website that makes a lot more sense than your rediculous chain email, that is the official DOS website. I would post a link, but mil.com is run by morons who fear links like Satan's spawn. quote: Many schools allow students’ participation throughout the day. Some schools ask students to speak as they normally would during class and remain silent during breaks and at lunch. There is no single way to participate, and students are encouraged to take part in the way that is the most positive and uplifting for their school. How would you, as a school administrator, punish a kid for choosing to remain silent during his or her lunch break? Sheesh, some of you people are not that bright, are ya?
quote: Parents should no longer passively countenance the political usurpation of public school classrooms through student silence.

content: You know, I get the idea of the "day of silence". quote: National youth-run effort using silence to protest the actual silencing of LGBT people due to harassment, bias and abuse in schools. But I don't think the response should be silence. Things like a day of silence is too "prayer-like" for my tastes. Instead of a day of silence it should be a day of talking about it to anyone you meet. Open a dialog.
quote: National youth-run effort using silence to protest the actual silencing of LGBT people due to harassment, bias and abuse in schools.
